repo.description: DSL for C APIs to aid consistency of naming schemes and comments.
repo.name: apidsl

body: # README - [x] Remove "sudo" in Docker build instructions. - Users are in "docker" group by Docker installation. - [x] Mark optional cleanup steps as such. For example the emoval of debian:-slim image etc. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/apidsl/35)

comment_regular_data.body: Docker build on Travis-CI fails in your last commit.
@nurupo Thanks! Argh… latest Debian stable is still "stretch" - got a little confused with "buster".

@nurupo Docker build is ok.

Why does it fail on host :question:

```text
ocaml setup.ml -build -yaccflags --table
+ ocamlfind ocamlopt -package unix -package ocamlbuild -linkpkg -package ppx_driver.ocamlbuild myocamlbuild.ml /home/travis/.opam/default/lib/ocamlbuild/ocamlbuild.cmx -o myocamlbuild
ocamlfind: Package `ppx_driver.ocamlbuild' not found
Command exited with code 2.
Compilation unsuccessful after building 1 target (0 cached) in 00:00:00.
E: Failure("Command ''/home/travis/.opam/default/bin/ocamlbuild' apigen.native -use-ocamlfind -plugin-tag 'package(ppx_driver.ocamlbuild)' -tag debug -tag tests -yaccflags --table' terminated with error code 10")
make[1]: *** [build] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory `/home/travis/build/TokTok/apidsl/src/.coverage'
~/build/TokTok/apidsl/src
make: *** [coverage] Error 2
make: Leaving directory `/home/travis/build/TokTok/apidsl/src'
The command "make -C src coverage" exited with 2.
```

The build was failing not because Buster is not Stable yet, but because:

```
bwrap: Creating new namespace failed: Operation not permitted
```

Somehow this error doesn't get triggered on Jessie and Stretch.

Also, there is little reason in bumping the distro version, since all the container does is build the apidsl binary. You actually want to use as old distro as possible, to make sure its glibc would be compatible with yours, as the apidsl binary produced is not statically linked.
@nurupo Reverted the update change -> same result. Seems like a "ppx driver" is missing or something.

commit.message:
removes "sudo" in docker build instructions

We can assume the user is in the "docker" group - Docker default installation.
